description.narrative: Agribusiness/Food Supply Chain Development: Through its expansion plan in the three countries, Lidl will have a beneficial impact on small to large local suppliers by applying its strict standards in food quality and safety and efficient operations and providing additional sales channels to local fresh and dry food producers through its Lidl network of stores in Europe. Benefits to low income consumers in small cities: Thanks to its modern discount format, the Project will contribute to expanding the access of low and middle income population in secondary and tertiary cities to affordable, diverse selection and high quality food products. Employment generation (direct and indirect): The Project is expected to create significant local direct employment (with a large participation of women, currently at above 60%). The Project has also the potential to generate a significant number of indirect jobs through retail supply chains and related services companies. Improved Green building standards: In line with its current practices in its existing markets, Lidl plans to be the local leader in energy efficiency by expansion of its building green stores equipped with standard setting green components, with potential demonstrational effect on local green building standards.

Lidl, a chain of discount grocery stores owned by the Schwarz Group (the Group or the Company) is implementing a long-term expansion plan in Bulgaria and Croatia and is planning to enter the Serbian market in 2014 by opening new Lidl discount stores (the Project). The Group, one of the largest European food retail discounters, has requested IFC to provide a long-term loan to its Bulgarian, Croatian and Serbian subsidiaries to partially finance the Project.
